Award.AwardTitle: Multiscale Weak Galerkin Methods for Flows in Highly Heterogeneous Media
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fluid flow in porous media is important in many areas, including oil extraction and recovery, environmental protection, energy conservation, and the design and operation of fuel cells, solar cells, and batteries. Development of accurate, efficient, and reliable numerical schemes to simulate such fluid flow has received considerable attention in mathematics and engineering communities over the past decade. However, mathematical modeling and numerical simulation of fluid flows in heterogeneous media and realistic settings remain a challenge. Much of the difficulty in porous media flow simulations is due to the involvement of different length scales, from macroscopic scale to microscopic scale. This research project aims to develop accurate, efficient, and reliable numerical algorithms for flows in porous media. Weak Galerkin finite element methods (WGFEMs) will be developed for flows in highly heterogeneous domains, porous media, and complex flows in heterogeneous media. The methods under development are anticipated to significantly advance the utility of numerical analysis for realistic scientific and engineering applications. Graduate students are involved in the project.

This project aims to develop new weak Galerkin (WG) finite element methods (FEMs) with excellent flexibility in element construction and mesh generation, suited to dealing with heterogeneous physical parameters. Additionally, it is envisioned that the new multiscale WGFEMs will be applicable in other fields, such as structural analysis, electromagnetic wave scattering, image processing, and computer vision. Collaboration with petroleum industry partners is planned in this research project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this proposed research is to develop effective numerical algorithms for solving  problems arising from science and engineering such as fluid flows in highly porous and highly heterogeneous media. Groundwater flow is an example of  elliptic problems  with rapidly oscillating  or high contrast coefficients. The complicated structure of porous media leads to  extremely variable or discontinuous physical parameters such as conductivity and viscosity in mathematical modeling. Although finite element methods have strong application in computational fluid dynamic, direct application of the finite element methods to these problems with multiscale can easily exceed the current limit of computing resources.


Weak Galerkin finite element methods have been developed to address the challenges. The modeling and simulation of fluid flows in porous media encounter not only multiphysics  and multiscale challenges, but also the difficulty of extremely complicated geometries. Weak Galerkin methods, by design, make use of discontinuous piecewise polynomials on finite element partitions with arbitrary shape of polygons and polyhedrons to deal with complicated geometries. Weak Galerkin methods have also been applied to solve problems in solid mechanics and material sciences including P-Laplacian problem,  Reissner-Mindlin plate and nonlinear conservation laws. Another novel finding is the introduction of a new stabilizer free weak Galerkin method, which reduces programming complexity significantly. Weak Galerkin and stabilizer free weak Galerkin  finite element methods make important contribution to finite element literatures.


Three Ph.D students were supported by this grant. Two of them obtained doctoral degree and found jobs in academics.


During this funding period, there are 50 refereed journal papers published and 40 invited presentations in conferences and universities.
